title: Violent man breaks Bunnings worker's jaw at bus stop in Brisbane
text:
Jailed: Alex John Beeston

A judge has warned a vigilante who attacked a Bunnings worker at a bus stop in a case of mistaken identity to seek help for his angry outbursts.

Alex John Beeston, 32, attacked and broke Edward Haynes' jaw at a bus stop in Capalaba, east of Brisbane, in April last year after believing he had attacked a woman.

He was found guilty this week of grievous bodily harm and common assault, and was sentenced in the Brisbane District Court on Wednesday to three-and-a-half years' jail, to be suspended after 19 months.

His trial was told Beeston confronted Mr Haynes, who was waiting to catch a bus home after work, after hearing a woman screaming.

He repeatedly demanded his name and ID, then chased Mr Haynes when he ran from him in fear.

He put Mr Haynes in a choke hold and punched him twice, breaking his jaw.

The court heard Mr Haynes, who required surgery, is now too scared to travel by bus and no longer loves his job.

Judge Julie Ryrie told Beeston, who has previously been convicted of assaulting an ex-partner, that he had no right to attack a complete stranger.

'You didn't have any basis at all to persist in asking him for ID, in following him, in chasing him and then punching him the way that you did,' she said.

She advised him to undergo an anger management course while behind bars.

Judge Ryrie said her sentence took into account the fact Beeston, a painter who was born in New Zealand, may be deported when released from jail.
